The last Grand Slam tennis tournament played in a calendar year is the US Open, which is typically held in late August and early September. The US Open has a rich history, with previous locations including Newport, Forest Hills, and Philadelphia. It is part of the calendar Grand Slam, which consists of the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. The concept of the calendar Grand Slam refers to winning all four major tournaments in a single calendar year. Additionally, there is the non-calendar year Grand Slam, which involves winning the four major tournaments consecutively but not within the same calendar year. 

The 1919 Australasian Championships, now known as the Australian Open, is significant as the last Grand Slam tournament of 1919. It has since become one of the major tournaments in the Grand Slam circuit. Furthermore, the Grand Slam Cup tournament, held in Munich from 1990 through 1999, was a prestigious event that featured winners of the four major tournaments competing for a substantial prize.

Answer:
The last Grand Slam tennis tournament played in a calendar year is the US Open, typically held in late August and early September. It is part of the calendar Grand Slam, which includes the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. The US Open has a rich history, with previous locations such as Newport, Forest Hills, and Philadelphia. Additionally, the 1919 Australasian Championships, now known as the Australian Open, is significant as the last Grand Slam tournament of 1919. The Grand Slam Cup tournament, held in Munich from 1990 through 1999, was also a prestigious event in the tennis world.
